question.text: If Adenine makes <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the DNA molecule, what will be the percentage of Thymine, Guanine and Cytosine in it?

solution.text: According to Chargaff's principle, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi></math> is equal to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Hence, if the total is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn></math> then <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> will also be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>30</mn><mo>.</mo></math> Likewise <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> will be <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn><mo>,</mo></math> so, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></math>.
